Dear Melynda Elizabeth Williams:
Attached is the Amended Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility.
Due to the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
1

Rule Code & CCI Licensing Rule 142: (1) An institution shall establish and
Section follow written health service policies and procedures addressing
Description all of the following: (e) Dispensing medication
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation 1:
On an unknown date last week, staff neglected to refill youth's
medication causing youth to the need to restart the medication
gradually. Youth has shown an increase in behavioral concerns
with staff and other youth which is believed to be a result of the
medication issue.
Allegation 2:
In addition, staff failed to follow agency policy requirements to
complete daily inventory of medications.
Investigation Interviews for Allegation 1:
On 09/23/2024 an email was sent to Area Manager expressing
concern that the facility may not be administering medication as
prescribed based on review of the medication log and interviews
of staff at an unannounced quarterly visit on 09/20/2024.
On 09/23/2024 an email was sent to Complainant inquiring about
any additional concerns.
On 09/23/2024 an email was sent to the assigned Foster Care
Worker requesting a return call.
On 09/23/2024 a telephone call was received from Foster Care
Worker. She advised that she received an email from Mott on
Tuesday and saw Youth A on Friday. She was advised by the
facility that Youth A’s behavior had escalated. Foster Care Worker
reported she spoke with the prescribing physician and was
advised that due to a missed dosage, the medication would have
to be gradually increased in order to return to the original dosage.
Youth A was previously prescribed 500mg and is now taking
50mg. Foster Care Worker expressed concern regarding the
medication mishap, but did not have any other concerns with the
facility.
On 09/25/2024 an onsite meeting was completed at Mott to initiate
the special investigation. An interview was completed with
Compliance Supervisor. She was advised of the nature of the
special investigation. She confirmed awareness of Youth A not
receiving medication due to it not being filled timely. A request
2

was made for a copy of the medical policy and procedures for the
agency.
On 09/25/2024 an interview was completed with Chief Program
Officer (CPO). A copy of the medical policy was provided. CPO
was advised of the allegations relative to the investigation. She
confirmed her knowledge that Youth A was not administered her
medication as the prescription had not been filled.
The following interviews were completed on 10/11/2024 at
Whaley’s Mott, unless otherwise specified.
CPO was interviewed. She reported prior to 9/1/24 her title was
Director of Clinical and Medical Services. She confirmed Youth A
had missed doses of her prescribed Clozapine. She reported that
documentation showed her last lab draw occurred on 8/19/2024.
CPO denied having a reason or knowledge of what led to the
missed medication for Youth A. She reported the Medical
Supervisor position is currently vacant, and the medical staff are
reporting to her. She reported the agency is looking to fill the
position soon and hope to hire a nurse for the position. She later
confirmed that Youth A had missed dosages of Clozapine in
August 2024.
Youth B was interviewed. She confirmed that she takes
medication two times per day. She reported that she goes to the
medical station in the morning for med pass. Youth B added that
sometimes the medical staff give the medication to staff for them
to pass it. She recalled there being a time when she did not
receive her medication. The house was on a bowling or skating
event and staff forgot to bring her medication for her evening
medication pass. She denied that she took the medication once
she returned home as it was too late. Youth B denied knowledge
of other youth not receiving their medication and reported that
staff are usually on top of things when it comes to the needs of the
youth.
Interview was held with Youth C. He confirmed that he is
prescribed medication, and it is administered daily by the medical
staff. He denied that he has ever missed taking his prescribed
medication. He reported that it is stored in the medical room and
is administered by the medical staff. He did recall that one time
he requested a PRN medication and it was unable to be given to
him because there was no one able to dispense it.
3

An interview was completed with Doctor. She confirmed that she
was the physician that prescribes the medication for Youth A. She
recalled that Youth A came to the facility already having been
prescribed Clozapine (to treat schizophrenia and Hallucinations)
and she continued it. Doctor stated she would not normally
prescribe this medication because if it is not properly monitored, it
could present an issue for the patient up to and including death.
She stated Youth A came to the facility taking 500 mg per day
(100 mg in the morning, 200 mg in the afternoon and 200 mg in
the evening). The dosage was reduced to 400 mg per day on
08/12/2024 after it was reported that Youth A had not taken the
morning dosage for three days. Doctor stated she always thought
the dosage was really high and took this as an opportunity to see
if the reduced dosage could be effective for Youth A. Doctor then
began to prescribe 400 mg per day (200 mg in the afternoon and
200 in the evening). On 9/16/2024 Doctor reported she was
called and advised that Youth A had missed some of her doses.
She reported that Youth A took her last dose on Friday 9/13 at
4pm. She denied that she was contacted prior to 9/16/24
regarding the missed doses. Doctor further advised that when
complete doses are missed, the patient has to restart the
medication at a lower dose (50 mg) and gradually increase all
while doing weekly blood draws (increase from the monthly
requirement). She advised the blood draws are to monitor the
white blood cell levels of the patient. Doctor reported in order to
prescribe Clozapine physicians must have certification via REMS
(Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy). REMS is a drug safety
program that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration can require
for certain medications with serious safety concerns to help
ensure the benefits of the medication outweigh its risks. Doctor
reported that blood draws are required monthly and results are
provided to the prescribing physician and the pharmacy to upload
into REMS. If the results are not uploaded, the pharmacy is not
able to dispense the medication to the patient. Doctor reported
that to her knowledge the REMS system, blood draws and refills
were up to date. Once informed of the missed doses, Doctor
restarted Youth A on the medication at 50 mg per day. As of now
she has increased to 150 mg per day (100 mg in the morning and
50 mg in the evening).
An attempted interview was completed with Youth A. She
refused to answer any questions and demanded to leave the
room. After unsuccessful attempts to engage her, she was
advised she could leave.
4

An interview was held with Therapist 1. She confirmed
knowledge that Youth A had missed some doses of her
medication. She confirmed that Youth A was struggling initially,
but that she has seen an improvement in her behavior. She
denied that she is directly involved in the prescribing or
administering of medication to youth at the facility.
An interview was held with Medical Staff 1. She reported she has
worked at the agency since May 2024. She confirmed that Youth
A missed doses of her prescribed medication of Clozapine. She
reported she believed it was due to miscommunication. She did
not think that a refill script was available. She recalled that to her
knowledge, Youth A was taken for her monthly blood draw.
Medical Staff 1 reported the last medical staff leaves at 9pm.
When asked what occurs if PRN meds are requested after 9pm,
she replied that on call CRT staff would pass those medications.
An interview was held with Medical Staff 2. She reported working
for the agency since June 2024. She confirmed that Youth A
missed doses of her Clozapine and took her last prescribed dose
on 9/13/24. She is not sure how Youth A ran out of medication
but believes the Doctor did not send the prescription over. When
medications are noticed to be getting low, the other medical staff
is notified. She does not recall who, if anyone, she notified
regarding the Clozapine for Youth A running low. She could not
recall notifying any of the administrative staff or the Doctor.
Tour of Medical Room:
The medical room where medication is stored and dispensed was
viewed. It was found to be properly secured with no visible
concerns.
Documents Reviewed:
Whaley’s Medical Department Policy and Procedures Manual
The manual noted the following:
• The medical supervisor will ensure medications are
administered to the child and youth during the appropriate
med pass times.
• Guarantee medication is available to youth with no
interruptions.
• Ensure all medication required for visits, transports or
activities is prepared and ready for the transporting staff
and all medication exchange forms are completed
accurately.
Whaley Childrens Home QuickMAR form for Youth A.
5

It documented that her last dose of Clozapine was administered
on 9/13/24 and medication was discontinued until it was resumed
on 9/16/24 with a different dose.
Interviews for Allegation #2:
The following interviews were completed on 10/11/2024 at
Whaley’s Mott, unless otherwise specified.
CPO was interviewed. She reported prior to 9/1/24 her title was
Director of Clinical and Medical Services. CPO confirmed medical
staff are required to complete a daily inventory of all medications.
A request was made for copies of the medication inventory logs
for the last 14 days. CPO returned and advised that she was
unable to provide them as they had not been completed daily.
An interview was held with Medical Staff 2. She reported working
for the agency since June 2024. She reported that a daily
inventory of medication is completed on second shift. When
requested, Medical Staff 2 was unable to provide copies of logs
documenting daily completion of inventory of medications.
Documents Reviewed:
Whaley’s Medical Department Policy and Procedures Manual
The manual noted the following:
• On each shift the medical aid will complete inventory for all
medications. The inventory will be documented in ink on
the inventory form and signed and dated. The medical
supervisor is responsible for reviewing the inventory log
daily.
Analysis Allegation 1:
At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to confirm non-compliance with the licensing rule. The
prescribing physician, medical staff and administrative staff all
reported and confirmed that Youth A missed her prescribed
medication dosage. In addition, review of the QuickMAR report
documents the missed dosage for Youth A.
Allegation 2:
Review of agency policy and review of daily medication inventory
logs confirmed non-compliance. The staff failed to consistently
complete the medication inventory as required by policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
